questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman presents with epistaxis, easy bruising and menorrhagia. There is no history of drug intake. Physical examination shows scattered petechiae and a normal-sized spleen. Her lab investigations are given below. Antibodies against which of the following can lead to this condition?

Platelet count - 37,000/μL

Bleeding time - 16 minutes

PT - 13 seconds

aPTT - 30 seconds

Peripheral blood smear - megathrombocytes
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). Autoantibodies seen in ITP are most often directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion due to the following findings:

  • Bleeding tendency - petechiae
  • Low platelet count, elevated bleeding time
  • Presence of megathrombocytes in the peripheral smear - a sign of accelerated thrombopoiesis
  • Female preponderance
  • Absence of splenomegaly

 Note: Prothrombin time (PT) is normal in ITP.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presented with sudden onset descending paralysis and blurred vision  3 days after the intake of canned food. On examination, the patient has quadriparesis with areflexia. Both the pupils are nonreactive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of acute onset descending flaccid paralysis with a history of consumption of canned food is suggestive of botulism.

The incubation period from ingestion of contaminated food to the onset of symptoms in food-borne botulism is usually 8–36 h but can be as long as 10 days and is dose-dependent. The clinical syndrome of botulism consists of bilateral cranial-nerve palsies that may progress to respiratory compromise, a bilateral descending flaccid paralysis of voluntary muscles, and even death.

Cranial nerve deficits may manifest as some of the following:

  • diplopia
  • dysarthria
  • dysphonia
  • ptosis
  • ophthalmoplegia
  • facial paralysis and impaired gag reflex

The absence of cranial nerve palsies makes botulism highly unlikely, as does a lack of cranial nerve deficits at the onset of illness. Pupillary reflexes may be depressed and fixed or dilated pupils are sometimes noted.

The cornerstones of treatment for botulism are meticulous intensive care and administration of botulinum antitoxin.

Option A: In poliomyelitis, weakness is generally asymmetric, more proximal than distal, and may involve the legs (most commonly), the arms, or the abdominal, thoracic, or bulbar muscles.

Option C: Guillain–Barre syndrome is usually associated with ascending flaccid paralysis.

Option D: Tetanus causes spastic paralysis.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with muscle weakness, vomiting, and seizures accompanied by focal neurological deficits. Her developmental milestones were normal during the previous visits. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and microscopic findings of muscle biopsy are shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with microscopy showing ragged red fibres is suggestive of MELAS (mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke).

It is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to complex I or complex IV deficiency. Patients have normal development previously and then present with symptoms of lactic acidosis and stroke (seizures with focal neurological deficits).

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead) as shown below.

Other mitochondrial inherited diseases:

  • Leigh’s disease
  • Leber hereditary optic neuropathy
  • Kearns–Sayre syndrome
  • Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia
  • Pearson syndrome

questions.text: A P3 woman bleeds profusely after delivery of the placenta. You initiate oxytocin infusion. The patient continues to bleed and the uterus fails to contract despite bimanual compression. She becomes tachycardic and hypotensive. What is the next best step in her management?
questions.solution:
Balloon tamponade is the next step in the management of atonic PPH unresponsive to medical management and bimanual uterine massage. 

Option A: Tight intrauterine packing has become unpopular due to the dangers of concealed bleeding and infections. It can be used in low-resource settings while shifting the patient to tertiary care centers.

Option C: Uterine artery ligation is done when tamponade fails (Bakri balloon and compression sutures).

Option D: Hysterectomy is the last option when all the other treatment modalities fail. Usually, the uterus contracts and bleeding stops with ligation or embolization. However, hysterectomy is done sooner rather than later in cases of placenta accreta and uterine rupture.

questions.text: A 47-year-old construction site worker is admitted for fever, nausea, vomiting, and pain abdomen radiating to the back. The next day he develops sudden onset breathlessness and hypoxia. He has been drinking daily for the past 10 years. He had a myocardial infarction 6 months back. His chest X-ray is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the chest X-ray finding is suggestive of ARDS (acute respiratory distress syndrome) secondary to acute pancreatitis. Acute pancreatitis gives rise to inflammatory processes and endothelial damage that results in ARDS. 

CXR features in ARDS:

  • Early findings -  normal or diffuse alveolar opacities (consolidation), bilateral and which obscure the pulmonary vascular markings
  • Late findings - these opacities progress to more extensive consolidation that is diffuse

Clinical disorders commonly associated with ARDS:

  • Direct lung injury:
    • Pneumonia
    • Aspiration of gastric contents
    • Pulmonary contusion
    • Near-drowning
    • Toxic inhalation injury
  • Indirect lung injury:
    • Sepsis
    • Severe trauma- multiple fractures, flail chest, head trauma, burns
    • Multiple transfusions
    • Drug overdose
    • Pancreatitis
    • Post-cardiopulmonary bypass

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with 6/6 vision in the right eye and vision for only hand movements in the left eye. On fundoscopy, the right eye appears normal. The left eye shows retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates, and telangiectatic vessels. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Unilateral decreased vision with retinal detachment, subretinal yellowish exudates and telangiectatic vessels in a young boy points to the diagnosis of Coats' disease.

Coats’ disease, described by Coats in 1908, affects boys three times more often than girls, has no reported racial or ethnic predilection, and is usually unilateral. The average age at diagnosis is 8–16 years. The clinical course is generally progressive. 

It is characterized by discrete zones of retinal vascular abnormalities like aneurysmal dilatation and leakage. It is associated with localized lipid deposition (hard exudates) and varying degrees of subretinal exudates. Vessels may appear telangiectatic, and they may have aneurysms that are grape-like, clustered, or light bulb-shaped. 

The image below depicts the typical vascular abnormalities with aneurysmal dilatation, telangiectasia, exudation, and severe lipid deposition in the macula which are seen in Coat's disease.

questions.text: A patient with recent-onset primary generalized epilepsy develops a skin reaction due to phenytoin sodium. What is the most appropriate course of action?

choices.text: Stop and restart phenytoin sodium after two weeks

questions.solution:
Hypersensitivity reaction to phenytoin warrants discontinuation of the drug. Switching to sodium valproate is the most appropriate course of action for this patient. 

Sodium valproate is one of the first-line agents indicated for GTCS. Clonazepam and ethosuximide are primarily used in absence seizures and are not indicated for GTCS. 

Clonazepam is indicated as adjunctive therapy in the absence seizures when first-line agents (ethosuximide, sodium valproate, lamotrigine) fail to control the seizures adequately.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with itchy lesions on her arm as shown. Her family history is positive for asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicting pruritic lesions at a flexural site along with a family history of atopy (asthma) is suggestive of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE). The scratch marks and excoriations shown in the image are due to pruritis, which is the hallmark feature of AD.

AD is a chronic relapsing inflammatory condition. It presents with erythematous macules, papules and vesicles that often start in early childhood, usually less than 2 years old. The lesions later become excoriated and lichenified. It is frequently associated with dryness of the skin and secondary infections. In infancy, the lesions initially appear on face (sparing the napkin area) and later on extensor aspect of knees and elbows as the child starts crawling. In later childhood and in adults, the principal site of involvement is flexures.

The filaggrin monomers in keratinocytes in the epidermis bind and aggregate keratin bundles and intermediate filaments to form the epidermal barrier. Any damage/dysfunction of this barrier is associated with an increased risk of developing AD. Damage to this barrier can be due to environmental factors (detergents, hard water, UV light) or local inflammatory reactions. Dysfunction of the barrier can be due to genetic mutation of the FLG gene leading to reduced filaggrin production or local immunomodulatory effects leading to reduced filaggrin expression.

Other options:

Option A: Seborrheic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by erythema, pruritus, scaling, flaking, or crusting of the skin. It is often associated with Malasezzia fungal infection. A milder form of seborrheic dermatitis of the scalp is commonly known as dandruff.

Option C: Allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) is an inflammatory condition caused due to a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type 4 hypersensitivity) to a specific allergen that comes into direct contact with the skin.Patients usually present with pruritus, erythema, swelling, papules, and papulovesicles. Some common allergens include nickel (found in artificial jewelry), PPD/Para phenylene diamine (in hair dye), chromate (in cement), rubber or latex, cosmetics, etc. Patch test (image below) is used for the diagnosis of ACD. 

Option D: Erysipelas is a bacterial skin infection caused by Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus) characterized by raised, erythematous sharply demarcated rapidly spreading skin lesions, along with systemic symptoms like fever and chills. The skin may also have a peau d'orange or orange peel-like appearance.

Related Pearl: UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (eczema)

In order to qualify as a case of atopic dermatitis (eczema) with the UK  diagnostic criteria, the child must have an itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child).

Plus three or more of the following:

  • Onset below age of 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
  • History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
  • History of a generally dry skin
  • Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first-degree relative in children under 4 years)
  • Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

questions.text: Following autopsy, an H&E stained specimen of the lung was obtained which is given below. What could be the likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of laminated swirls of squamous cells in the pulmonary arteriole which is characteristically seen in amniotic fluid embolism(AFE).

AFE is a life-threatening obstetric emergency characterized by sudden cardiorespiratory collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The underlying cause is the infusion of amniotic fluid or fetal tissue into the maternal circulation via a tear in the placental membranes or rupture of uterine veins.

Findings at autopsy include:

  • Presence in the maternal pulmonary micro-vasculature of-
    • Squamous cells shed from fetal skin
    • Lanugo hair
    • Fat from vernix caseosa
    • Mucin derived from the fetal respiratory or gastrointestinal tract 
  • Marked pulmonary edema
  • Diffuse alveolar damage
  • Presence of fibrin thrombi in many vascular beds due to DIC

questions.text: A multiparous woman notices a bulge at the vulva that diminishes in size on lying down. She also finds it difficult to initiate micturition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a cystocoele.

A cystocele is the herniation of the urinary bladder into the vagina. It is usually associated with uterine prolapse, and presents with the following features:

  • Mass descending in the vagina - 
    • Increases in size on straining and coughing
    • Reduces on lying down, or manual reduction
  • Difficulty in micturition - difficulty initiating, straining required
  • Mass needs to be pushed inwards to urinate - repositioning of cystocele required
  • Increased frequency of micturition
  • Backache - due to stretching of uterosacral ligaments

questions.text: A 6-year-old child abruptly develops fever, oliguria, periorbital edema and smoky cola-colored urine  2-weeks after recovery from sore throat. His renal biopsy image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology image are suggestive of nephritic syndrome, occurring as a consequence of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

The PSGN patient presents with hematuria, red cell casts in the urine, azotemia, oliguria, hypertension, mild to moderate proteinuria, and edema (features of nephritic syndrome)

The classic histopathology picture is of enlarged, hypercellular glomeruli with influx of leucocytes (endocapillary proliferation).

questions.text: A 40-year-old man with bronchiectasis presents with progressive focal neurologic deficits and symptoms related to increased intracranial pressure. On lumbar puncture, the CSF is found to have a high white cell count and an increased protein concentration, but the glucose content is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Brain abscess is the most likely diagnosis in the above patient with progressive focal neurologic deficits and increased intracranial pressure.

Predisposing conditions for brain abcess:

  • Acute bacterial endocarditis, which may give rise to multiple brain abscesses.
  • Congenital heart diseases with right to left shunt.
  • Chronic pulmonary disease, as in bronchiectasis.
  • Systemic disease with immunosuppression.

Organisms involved are:

  • Streptococcus spp. and Staphylococcus spp. (most common aerobic organisms)
  • Bacteroides fragilis and Peptostreptococcus spp.(most common anaerobic organisms).

Foci of organisms in brain abscess:

  • Direct implantation of organisms
  • Local extension from adjacent foci (mastoiditis, paranasal sinusitis)
  • Hematogenous spread (from primary foci of heart, lungs, bones of extremities, dental extraction)

CSF analysis in brain abscess:

Parameters Observation
WBC Increased
Proteins Increased
Glucose Decreased (but it will be normal in a significant proportion of individuals)

Note: In Robbins and Cotran's Pathology of Diseases- edition 9 page no.1273, it is given that in a typical brain abscess patient, the glucose in the CSF will be normal.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child was given intravenous succinylcholine for rapid sequence intubation at a dose of 0.5 mg/kg. During intubation, a masseteric spasm was noted. Temperature and BP were normal. What would be your first line of management?

choices.text: Cool the child by using cooling blanket

questions.solution:
The first line of management in this child would be to increase the dose of succinylcholine.

The incidence of muscle spasms without any symptoms and signs of malignant hyperthermia frequently results from an inadequate dosage of succinylcholine. Succinylcholine dosage for intubation is 1-2mg/kg

Conditions to be ruled out in isolated masseteric spasm:

  • Inadequate dose of succinylcholine (less than the recommended dose of 1 mg/kg)
  • Inadequate time for the onset of succinylcholine action
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy, myotonia congenita, and other muscle disorders
  • Temporomandibular joint dislocation

Confusion-buster: Although an increase in the tone of the masseter is considered to be an early indicator of malignant hyperthermia, this finding is not consistently associated with it.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old man presents with bleeding gums for 20 days. He has gingival hyperplasia, hepatosplenomegaly, and lymphadenopathy. Investigations done are given below. Bone marrow biopsy shows 100% cellularity with many blasts cells that are peroxidase negative and non-specific esterase positive. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 11 g/dL

Platelet count: 95,000 platelets/mm3

WBC count: 45000 cells/mm3.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia-M5 (AML-M5) or acute monocytic leukemia.

The patients with AML - M5 develop organomegaly, lymphadenopathy, gingival hyperplasia, CNS involvement, and other tissue infiltration. The bone marrow aspirate shows 20% or more blasts. Monoblasts have folded or lobulated nuclei, lack Auer rods, and are nonspecific esterase positive.

Myeloperoxidase is present in the azurophilic granules of neutrophils and their precursors. It is positive in AML M1, M2, M3, M4 and negative in AML M0. Monoblasts and monocytes may be negative or positive. When positive, the granules are smaller than in neutrophils and diffusely scattered throughout the cytoplasm.

The image given below shows bone marrow aspirate in AML - M5.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the OPD with high fever, chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis. The patient also complains of watery diarrhea. The direct fluorescent antibody stained film of his pleural fluid is given below. Identify the most likely etiologic agent.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing fluorescent organisms in the direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) stained film of pleural fluid suggest the diagnosis of Legionnaire's disease, caused by Legionella pneumophila.

Two distinct clinical patterns of legionellosis have been identified:

  • Legionnaires' disease presents with fever, non-productive cough, and dyspnea rapidly progressing to pneumonia if left untreated. Patients can also develop a hyponatremia. Diarrhea and encephalopathy are also common. It is often included in the differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia. Atypical pneumonia is also caused by: 
    • Chlamydia pneumonia
    • Chlamydia psittaci
    • Mycoplasma pneumonia
    • Coxiella burnetii
    • Viruses such as influenza virus, adenovirus and respiratory syncytial virus
  • Pontiac fever is a milder, non-fatal, influenza-like illness with fever, chills, myalgia, and headache.

Other options:

Option A: Chlamydia pneumonia causes pharyngitis, sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia. It has also been associated with adult onset asthma. Outbreaks have been reported in closed communities. Real-time PCR is used for its diagnosis.

Option C: Haemophilus influenzae typically causes pneumonia in infants. While the primary infections occur due to capsulated strains, bronchopneumonia may occur as a secondary infection due to non-capsulated strains. Gram stain and culture are used for diagnosis.

Option D: Klebsiella pneumonia causes fatal pneumonia, which occurs in middle -aged or older persons with risk factors such as alcoholism, chronic bronchopulmonary disease or diabetes mellitus. Gram stain and culture are used for diagnosis.

questions.text: A patient of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis is on antitubercular drugs. After a few months, he develops an inability to distinguish between red and green color. Most likely drug causing these symptoms is:
questions.solution:
The most likely drug causing these symptoms is Ethambutol.

Optic neuritis resulting in decreased visual acuity and loss of ability to differentiate red from green is the most serious adverse effect of ethambutol.

Tests of visual acuity and red-green discrimination before the start of therapy and periodically thereafter are recommended.

questions.text: A dose of oral 58-Co-labeled cobalamin was administered to a 65-year-old woman. The 24-hour urinary excretion of radiolabeled cobalamin was found to be < 10%. The test was repeated after a 5-day course of antibiotics and showed urinary excretion > 10%. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario refers to Schilling's test done for the determination of the cause of B12 deficiency. Improvement of urinary B12 excretion > 10% after antibiotic administration is suggestive of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).

Related Pearl: Schilling Test

The Schilling test is done to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency. It involves the administration of radiolabeled vitamin B12 followed by the 24-hour collection of urine. The test is then repeated with an additional component that can promote vitamin B12 absorption. If the additional component is able to correct the defect and radiolabeled vitamin B12 is absorbed, it will be detected in the urine.

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with periorbital swelling as shown below. She complains of significant visual impairment and a fungal etiology is suspected. What is the most appropriate drug for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of invasive mucormycosis in the form of orbital cellulitis. Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukaemia, lymphoma and other immunocompromised states. The most prevalent species is Rhizopus Oryza. 

Invasive mucormycosis has recently emerged as a life-threatening complication of COVID-19 in India. It is an opportunistic infection seen even in mild to moderate COVID patients with strong predisposing factors like hyperglycemia / uncontrolled diabetes. Diabetic patients receiving corticosteroids / immunosuppressants for COVID-19 treatment are exceptionally vulnerable to develop mucormycosis due to the risk of steroid-induced hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man has lenticonus and end-stage renal disease now. His maternal uncle also died of the same illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presentation of a male patient with lenticonus and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) with a family history of the renal disease is highly suggestive of Alport syndrome.

Alport syndrome:

It is a form of hereditary nephritis, is caused by mutations in genes encoding GBM type IV collagen.

The disease is inherited as an X-linked trait in approximately 85% of cases. Autosomal-recessive and autosomal-dominant pedigrees also exist.

It manifests as hematuria with progression to chronic renal failure, accompanied by nerve deafness and various eye disorders, including lens dislocation, posterior cataracts, and corneal dystrophy.

Light microscopy: Glomeruli appear normal until late in the disease course; ESRD can show histological features of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis and tubulointerstitial fibrosis.

Electron microscopy: Irregular thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) and splitting, producing a distinctive basket-weave appearance

Immunofluorescence: No deposits

Other options:

  • Autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney is ruled out because there is no association of ADPKD with lenticonus.
  • Thin basement membrane lesion (benign familial hematuria) is another form of hereditary nephritis where hearing loss, ocular abnormalities, and a family history of renal failure are absent.
  • Goodpasture syndrome is an immune-mediated disease with antibodies against the alpha-3 chain of GBM type IV collagen; it is not hereditary.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient complains of the following intensely itchy rash over his elbows, knees, buttocks, and upper back. He has been having persistent watery loose stools for the past 3 months and reports feeling more tired than usual. A complete blood count shows microcytic, hypochromic anemia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario along with the given image showing pruritic, multiple, grouped papules and vesicles located on extensor aspects is suggestive of dermatitis herpetiformis. 

It is associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy or celiac disease. It is also associated with HLA DQ2/DQ8/B8. Deposition of IgA antitransglutaminase antibodies in the dermal papillae results in subepidermal blisters and vesicles.

This condition is associated with a small increase in the risk of T-cell lymphoma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old hypertensive man complains of fever, migraine, loss of appetite, and myalgia. On examination, splinter hemorrhages and palpable purpura are noted. On CT angiography, aneurysm and stenosis of medium-sized vessels are observed. What is the type of hypersensitivity reaction associated with this disease?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is polyarteritis nodosa. It is an example of a type III hypersensitivity reaction.

In type III hypersensitivity, immune complexes may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

The pathogenesis of systemic immune complex disease can be divided into three phases:

  1. Formation of immune complexes
  2. Deposition of immune complexes
  3. Inflammation and tissue injury.

Examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions: 

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • SLE
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction
  • Farmer’s lung
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Type II lepra reaction
  • Henoch Schonlein purpura

questions.text: The magenta-colored tongue is seen in which vitamin deficiency?
questions.solution:
Magenta-colored tongue seen in vitamin B2 deficiency.

Riboflavin deficiency is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. Riboflavin provides the reactive moieties of the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD).

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include:

  • Corneal neovascularization
  • Cheilosis or angular stomatitis (cracking or scaling of lip borders and corners of the mouth)
  • Magenta-colored tongue
  • Seborrheic dermatitis

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis is as shown. What is the most probable underlying acid-base disorder?

pH- 7.24

pCO2- 60 mmHg

pO2- 52 mmHg

HCO3- - 27 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis.

Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change.

Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. 

Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following formula:

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 X Δ PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the patient is not acute)

Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L

Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L.

The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also.

But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg

questions.text: The patient presents with pigmentation of the face as shown in the image below and gradually increasing backache and stiffness. The X-ray image of the spine is shown. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical images show the accumulation of blackish discoloration on the face and the X-Ray shows calcification of the intervertebral discs. These findings are associated with alkaptonuria.

Alkaptonuria is a condition caused due to the deficiency of homogentisic acid oxidase. This results in the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

This condition is associated with the following symptoms:

  • Black ochronotic pigmentation (Alkapton bodies) of cartilage and collagenous tissue
  • Homogentisic aciduria (patient’s urine contains elevated levels of homogentisic acid, which is oxidized to a dark pigment on standing)
  • Large joint arthritis
  • Calcification of intervertebral discs known as as ochronotic spondyloarthropathy

questions.text: A young man presents to the ER with complaints of sudden onset nausea, vomiting, and four episodes of passing loose stools. He gives a history of having food from a nearby restaurant three hours ago. Which of the following organisms is most likely implicated here?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical history, the patient is most likely suffering from gastroenteritis caused by Staphylococcus aureus. 

Staphylococcus causes nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea 2-6 hrs after the consumption of contaminated food. Other organisms causing food poisoning within the same time period of 2-6 hrs are the emetic strains of Bacillus cereus.

Gastroeneteritis is caused by enterotoxin produced by S. aureus. It is a preformed toxin that is relatively heat stable while most of the other exotoxins are heat-labile. It stimulates the vagus nerve and vomiting centre of the brain and also stimulates intestinal peristaltic activity. Eight antigenic types of enterotoxin are currently known of which is Type  A toxin is responsible for most cases.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with dry mouth and difficulty swallowing solid food. Physical examination reveals enlargement of her parotid glands, along with marked dryness of her buccal mucosa. Laboratory examination shows the presence of both SS-A and SS-B antibodies. Which of the following statements is not true about this condition?

choices.text: About 75% of patients have rheumatoid factor
Patients are at high risk for development of B-cell lymphomas
Lacrimal gland is a major target for this disease

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in a 55-year-old female patient with dry eyes, dry mouth; difficulty swallowing solid food; and the findings of enlarged parotid gland, dry buccal mucosa, and antibody positivity for SS-A and SS-B is Sjogren syndrome. Glomerular lesions are extremely rare in Sjögren syndrome.

Defects of tubular function, including renal tubular acidosis, uricosuria, and phosphaturia, are often seen and are associated histologically with tubulointerstitial nephritis.

Lacrimal and salivary glands are the major targets of this disease, while the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts and the vagina may also be involved. The characteristic decrease in tears and saliva (sicca syndrome) is the result of lymphocytic infiltration and fibrosis of the lacrimal and salivary glands. The infiltrate contains predominantly activated CD4+ helper T cells and some B cells, including plasma cells.

Antibodies detected are:

  • Rheumatoid factor - seen in 75% of patients, whether or not coexisting rheumatoid arthritis is present
  • Anti-nuclear antibodies (ANAs)
  • SS-A (Ro) - associated with early disease onset, longer disease duration, and extra-glandular manifestations, such as cutaneous vasculitis and nephritis
  • SS-B (La)

These patients are at high risk for the development of B-cell lymphomas. About 60% of patients have another accompanying autoimmune disorder, such as rheumatoid arthritis, and these patients also have the symptoms and signs of that disorder.

Biopsy of the lip (to examine minor salivary glands) is essential for the diagnosis of Sjögren syndrome.

The image shows an enlargement of the salivary gland with intense lymphocytic and plasma cell infiltration with ductal epithelial hyperplasia in the salivary gland.

Note: Mikulicz syndrome is characterized by lacrimal and salivary gland enlargement from any cause, including sarcoidosis, lymphomas, and other tumors.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child with the complaints that he hasn't begun walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical manifestations point to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Its symptoms are albinism with vision problems, which include:

  • Strabismus
  • Photophobia
  • Nystagmus
  • Impaired vision or blindness
  • Astigmatism

Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with blurring of vision in the right eye. Examination reveals mild iritis, severe vitritis, and a focal necrotic lesion on the macula. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Monocular iritis, severe vitritis with a focal necrotic lesion on the macula is a classical description of ocular toxoplasmosis. 

Ocular toxoplasmosis is caused by Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular protozoan.  It causes severe recurrent attacks of posterior uveitis in adults, due to reactivation at previously inactive cyst-containing scars. A single inflammatory focus of fluffy white retinitis or retinochoroiditis associated with a pigmented scar ("satellite lesion") is typical. "Headlight in the fog" is the classic description of a white retinal inflammatory nidus viewed through vitritis. "Spill-over" anterior uveitis is common.

Treatment:

  • Prednisolone (1 mg/kg) is given initially and tapered according to clinical response. 
  • Pyrimethamine is administered as a loading dose of 75–100 mg for 1–2 days followed by 25–50 mg daily for 4 weeks in combination with oral folinic (not folic) acid 5 mg three times a week to retard thrombocytopenia, leukopenia, and folate deficiency. 
  • Sulfadiazine 1 g four times daily for 3–4 weeks is usually given in combination with pyrimethamine. 
  • Intravitreal therapy with clindamycin (1 mg) and dexamethasone (400 μg) may be as effective as triple therapy in reactivated infection.

The image shows the characteristic "headlight in the fog" appearance:

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman who is taking OCPs presents with weakness and fatigue. Her laboratory investigations and peripheral smear are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb - 5 gm%

TLC - 1200 cells/mm3

Platelet count - 60,000/μL

MCV - 102 fl

MCH - 40 pg/cell
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of megaloblastic anaemia due to the following reasons:

  • History of OCP use
  • Hemogram shows decreased hemoglobin and increased MCV
  • Peripheral smear shows anisopoikilocytosis, macroovalocytes, and hypersegmented neutrophils

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the casualty with palpitations and dizziness. His heart rate is 170/min and his blood pressure was 70/40 mm Hg. His ECG is given below. What is the first line of management?
questions.solution:
This patient has supraventricular tachycardia with evidence of hemodynamic deterioration. Immediate treatment would be cardioversion (50-100J).

If the patient were hemodyamically stable, initial treatment would be vagal maneuvers (Valsalva maneuver) in awake patients. This is because vagal maneuvers alone can terminate approximately 20% to 25% of reentry supraventricular tachycardias (SVTs).

If this is unsuccessful, then iv adenosine 6 mg is given. If necessary another dose of adenosine 12 mg may be administered after 1-2 minutes.

If the drug is administered via a central venous catheter, then these doses are reduced to 3 mg and 6 mg respectively.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria after UTI. Histopathology showed mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation. The following finding is seen on immunofluorescence, which was positive for C3 and negative for IgG. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, histopathology findings of mesangial widening and endocapillary proliferation, as well as immunofluorescence showing mesangial deposits are suggestive of IgA nephropathy (Berger's disease).

It is the most common type of glomerulonephritis worldwide. It is characterized by recurrent hematuria/ nephritic syndrome and the presence of prominent IgA deposits in the mesangium. Patients generally present with gross hematuria after respiratory, gastrointestinal or urinary tract infection.

The systemic variant of IgA nephropathy is called Henoch–Schönlein purpura. It is a disorder of children which presents with similar renal manifestations with characteristic IgA deposits in the mesangium in about one-third of the patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with shortness of breath and fatigue. She has a medical history of limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Her pulmonary function test results are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above PFT pattern shows near-normal FVC, increased FEV1%, and markedly decreased DLCO. This along with the given history is suggestive of pulmonary artery hypertension(PAH). It is more commonly associated with limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Option B: Interstitial lung disease is a restrictive lung disease. In ILD, the FVC is usually,<80% of the predicted value. It is more commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis.

Options C and D: Congestive heart failure and bronchiectasis have obstructive pathology. They would have decreased FEV1% and normal DLCO.

questions.text: An 18-month-old child is brought to OPD with complaints of blood in his urine. Examination reveals a non-tender mass in the left flank that does not cross the midline. Blood pressure is also found to be elevated. Imaging reveals a left renal tumor and surgical resection is planned. The gross appearance of the mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing a well-circumscribed tumor with multiple necrotic, hemorrhagic, and cystic changes in the upper pole of the kidney are suggestive of a nephroblastoma or Wilms' tumor. 

It is the most common primary renal tumor of childhood (2-5 years of age). Around 10% of cases are associated with genetic syndromes and gonadal dysgenesis may be seen. 

Clinical manifestations of Wilms' tumor include:

  • Large abdominal mass - usually unilateral and does not cross the midline
  • Abdominal pain
  • Hematuria
  • Hypertension
  • Intestinal obstruction (in some cases) 

Nephrogenic rests are the precursor lesions of Wilms' tumor and suggest an increased risk of developing a contralateral Wilms' tumor.

questions.text: A per-vaginal examination performed on a lady in labor reveals multiple painful tiny vesicular ulcers over the vulva and vaginal walls. A slide showing the microscopic findings is given below. What is the best step in the management of delivery in this patient?

choices.text: Give tocolytics and treat the infection

questions.solution:
Painful genital ulcers and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy are suggestive of herpes virus infection. The cytological image showing multinucleate giant cells, Tzanck cells confirms the diagnosis of HSV. The best step in the management of delivery in this patient is a cesarean section. 

Herpes infection in the newborn may occur during birth, particularly if the mother has genital lesions due to HSV-2. In such cases, a cesarean section may prevent neonatal infection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presents to the OPD with odynophagia and swelling. He is diagnosed with Ludwig’s angina. How might you describe the swelling?

choices.text: Tender fluctuant swelling in the floor of mouth
Tender fluctuant swelling in the parotid region
Woody hard swelling in the floor of mouth
Woody hard swelling in the parotid region

questions.solution:
Ludwig's angina presents as a tender woody hard swelling on the floor of the mouth.

There can be marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying degrees of trismus. The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward, threatening the airway. Laryngeal edema may also be present.

Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess. Incision and drainage show salted pork appearance.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male complains of dysphagia and regurgitation of food that has been eaten 3 days back. He has foul breath and a gurgling sound is heard on swallowing. 
The most likely diagnosis is _____
questions.solution:
The history is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum. If often presents with the following:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Gurgling sound on swallowing
  • Aspiration

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

questions.text: A patient with mitral stenosis had to undergo surgery. A pre-anesthetic checkup revealed increased liver enzymes. Which of the following inhalational agents would be most preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
Xenon is the preferred inhalational agent in the above given clinical scenario.

Xenon is considered to have minimal effects on the cardiovascular system. It is an inert gas and does not undergo metabolism. Therefore, it does not cause any cardiotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, and nephrotoxicity. 

Xenon exerts anesthetic and analgesic effects at various receptors in CNS. The most important actions are:

  • Non-competitive antagonism of NMDA receptor
  • Agonism at the TREK channel (a member of two-pore K+ channel family)

Options B and D: Enflurane and sevoflurane (fluorinated anesthetics) decrease arterial blood pressure (due to systemic vasodilation) and cardiac output.

Option C: Halothane is hepatotoxic.

questions.text: In a patient who is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, what does declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc indicate?
questions.solution:
In patients who are both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total anti-HBc are indicative of chronic infective hepatitis.

Anti-HBc IgM antibody signifies acute infection/window period, whereas, the presence of IgG anti-HBc indicates chronic infection. However, there is no test available to directly detect the IgG anti-HBC. Over a period of months, the IgM anti-HBc antibodies are replaced by the IgG anti-HBc antibodies. Thus a decline of IgM antibodies in the presence of rising total anti-HBC indicates that the IgM is being converted to IgG and thus the infection is chronic.  

HBeAg, HBV-DNA, and DNA polymerase appear in serum soon after HBsAg, and all signify active viral replication.

Occasionally, mutated strains of HBV emerge that do not produce HBeAg but are replication-competent and express HBcAg.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA

questions.text: A young boy was rushed to the emergency room with complaints of respiratory distress and high-grade fever. The microscopy and culture of the sputum showed gram-positive cocci with α-hemolytic activity on blood agar. Which of the following antibiotics is the pathogen most likely susceptible to?
questions.solution:
Sputum showing gram-positive cocci with α-hemolytic activity in a patient with high-grade fever and respiratory distress is suggestive of pneumococcal pneumonia. Pneumococci show optochin susceptibility.

Both Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans produce α-hemolysis on blood agar. The optochin sensitivity test is done to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae from commensal-like viridans Streptococci.

The image given below shows the classification of gram-positive bacteria.

Optochin sensitivity is observed using the disc diffusion method.

The image given below shows a sensitivity testing plate of Streptococcus pneumoniae.

Related Pearl: Differentiation between Streptococcus pneumoniae and Streptococcus viridans

Characteristics Streptococcus pneumoniae Streptococcus viridans
Morphology Lanceolate diplococci Cocci in chains
Capsule Capsulated Non-capsulated
Quellung Test Positive Negative
Colonies Initially Dome Shaped, Later Draughtsman Colonies Dome shaped
Growth in Liquid Media Uniform Turbidity Granular Turbidity, powdery deposit
Bile solubility Bile soluble Bile insoluble
Inulin fermentation Positive Negative
Optochin sensitivity Sensitive Resistant
Intraperitoneal inoculation in Mice Fatal infection Non-pathogenic
Hemolysis Alpha-hemolytic (under aerobic conditions) or Beta-hemolytic (under anaerobic conditions) Alpha hemolytic or non-hemolytic

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman with mild chest pain has a mid-systolic click, followed by a late systolic murmur. There is no history of rheumatic heart disease. Which of the following is histopathology of the mitral valve most likely to show?

choices.text: Myxomatous degeneration and attenuation of the collagenous fibrosa layer

questions.solution:
The patient is most likely to have mitral valve prolapse, and the most likely finding is myxomatous degeneration and attenuation of the collagenous fibrosa layer.

In mitral valve prolapse (MVP), one or both mitral valve leaflets are floppy and prolapse, or balloon back, into the left atrium during systole. The female-to-male ratio is 7:1. The characteristic anatomic change in MVP is interchordal ballooning (hooding) of the mitral leaflets. The affected leaflets are often enlarged, redundant, thick, and rubbery.

The key histologic change in the tissue is marked thickening of the spongiosa layer, with the deposition of mucoid (myxomatous) material, called myxomatous degeneration. Attenuation of the collagenous fibrosa layer of the valve is seen.

Most individuals diagnosed with MVP are asymptomatic. On auscultation, a mid-systolic clicks, sometimes followed by a mid to late systolic murmur is heard. The minority of patients have chest pain mimicking angina and a subset has dyspnea, presumably related to valvular insufficiency.

Complications:

  • Infective endocarditis
  • Mitral insufficiency
  • Stroke or other systemic infarcts
  • Arrhythmias

In rare cases, MVP is the only finding in sudden cardiac death.

Option A: Degenerative calcific deposits are seen in calcific valvular degeneration.

Option C: Lymphocytes and macrophages may be seen in Aschoff bodies in rheumatic heart disease.

Option D: Fibrin, inflammatory cells, and bacteria are seen in infective endocarditis.

Image: Normal heart valve and myxomatous mitral valve. In myxomatous valves, the collagen in the fibrosa is loose and disorganized; proteoglycan deposition (asterisk) in the spongiosa is markedly expanded; and elastin in the atrialis is disorganized.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman visits a gynecologist with complaints of irregular and infrequent menstrual cycles. She is also upset that she has gained 12 kg over the past few months. Her face appears as shown in the image below. Her blood pressure at this visit is 144/98 mm Hg and she has multiple purple striae over her abdomen. Which of the following investigations should you advise this patient?

choices.text: Serum testosterone levels and abdominal USG

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing moon facies with acne and hirsutism are suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome. It can be diagnosed with the help of a single midnight serum cortisol measurement.

Option A: Cosyntropin (ACTH) stimulation test is used for the diagnosis of Addison's disease.

Options C and D: Serum testosterone, abdominal USG, and LH: FSH ratio, are used to confirm a diagnosis of the polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS). Though PCOS can present with similar features, it is not typically associated with moon facies, purple striae, or hypertension.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hematuria, intermittent hemoptysis and chronic sinusitis. His chest radiograph shows multiple opacities and cavities. Renal biopsy suggests focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?

choices.text: Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of Wegener's granulomatosis. It is associated with PR3- ANCA (and not MPO- ANCA) in about 95% of cases.

Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis/Wegener granulomatosis is a necrotizing vasculitis characterized by a triad of necrotizing inflammation:

  • Necrotizing granulomas of the upper respiratory tract or the lung
  • Necrotizing or granulomatous vasculitis affecting small to medium-sized vessels, most prominently in the lungs
  • Focal necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis

Males are affected more often than females. The most common clinical features include persistent pneumonitis with bilateral nodular and cavitary infiltrates, chronic sinusitis, mucosal ulcerations of the nasopharynx, and evidence of renal disease.

Image: Chest radiograph showing pulmonary granulomatosis

Related Pearl: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (previously called Wegener’s granulomatosis) is a necrotising vasculitis of small arteries and veins along with granuloma formation.

It presents as a triad of upper and lower respiratory tract involvement with glomerulonephritis.

Important organs involved are:

  • Upper respiratory tract- Presents with paranasal sinus pain, serous otitis media, nasal septal perforation.
  • Lower respiratory tract- Presents with cough, hemoptysis, and multiple bilateral cavitary nodular infiltrates.
  • Renal- Presents with rapidly progressive renal failure, crescentic glomerulonephritis.
  • Eye- Presents with conjunctivitis, scleritis, episcleritis and dacryocystitis
  • Skin- Papules, vesicles, palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules.

Histopathology shows necrotizing vasculitis of small arteries and vein with granuloma formation.

The important laboratory features are elevated ESR, positive cANCA  antibodies and mild elevation of rheumatoid factor.

Treatment:

  • Induction phase- Cyclophosphamide combined with steroids
  • Remission phase- Methotrexate/Azathioprine

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms of frequent urination, enuresis, nocturia, in the absence of glucosuria. Which of the following parameters of a urinary test will help in confirming the diagnosis of Diabetes insipidus?

choices.text: 24h volume  > 50 ml/kg per day and Osmolarity > 300mosm/L
24h volume  > 40 ml/kg per day  and Osmolarity < 300mosm/L
24h volume > 50  ml/kg per day and Osmolarity < 250 mosm/L
24h volume > 40  ml/kg per day and Osmolarity < 250 mosm/L

questions.solution:
The clinical diagnosis for diabetes insipidus is confirmed when the following observations are made:

  • 24h urine volume exceeds 40-50 mL/kg per day, and
  • Urine osmolarity is below 300 mOsm/L.

questions.text: A critically ill patient was given an infusion of an intravenous anesthetic at a dose of 4mg/kg/hour. 48 hours later, the patient developed refractory bradycardia, and there was evidence of rhabdomyolysis on investigations. Which agent is most likely implicated?
questions.solution:
The given features point towards a diagnosis of propofol infusion syndrome. It is a rare but lethal syndrome seen when the dose of propofol infusion is > 4 mg/kg/hour for 48 hours or longer.

This syndrome is common in children and critically ill adults.

Clinical features:

  • Acute refractory bradycardia leading to asystole in the presence of one or more of the following:
    • Metabolic acidosis (base deficit >10 mmol/L)
    • Rhabdomyolysis
    • Hyperlipidemia
    • Enlarged or fatty liver
  • Other features -  cardiomyopathy with acute cardiac failure, skeletal myopathy, hyperkalemia, hepatomegaly, and lipemia.

The symptoms and signs are the results of muscle injury and the release of intracellular toxic contents. It is due to defect in mitochondrial metabolism and electron transport chain function.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) presents with complaints of recurrent postprandial abdominal pain associated with vomiting and diarrhea. Abdominal examination shows no tenderness or rigidity. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postprandial abdominal pain in the background of CAD is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia(CMI). The most common cause of chronic mesenteric ischemia is atherosclerotic disease.

The three classic symptoms pathognomonic of CMI are:

  • Postprandial pain (crampy periumbilical abdominal pain within 30 minutes of meals)
  • Food fear (foods that precipitate symptoms are avoided by the patient and unintentional weight loss can result)
  • Significant weight loss

CT angiogram demonstrates both the arterial lesion and the patterns of collateral blood flow.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and stenting have gained acceptance as the first line of therapy for mesenteric ischemia. 

Nutcracker syndrome refers to compression of the left renal vein, most commonly between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, with impaired blood outflow often accompanied by distention of the distal portion of the vein. Most commonly presents with hematuria, flank pain, and varicoceles. 

CT image of nutcracker syndrome showing compression of the LRV between the aorta and the SMA:

questions.text:
During a master health check-up, a 25-year-old woman was found to have the following lab values. Which of the following will help in establishing a diagnosis in this patient?

Hemoglobin - 10g/dl

MCV - 75 fL

MCH - 25 pg

Peripheral smear - Microcytes with target cells

Iron profile - Normal

Vitamin B12 and folate levels - Normal
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is consistent with β-thalassemia minor. The diagnosis can be established by hemoglobin electrophoresis.

This condition presents with the following features: 

  • Microcytes (N: 80-96 fL)
  • Hypochromic (N: 27-33 pg)
  • Mild anemia
  • Target cells 
  • Normal iron profile 

Hemoglobin electrophoresis findings are as follows:

  •  ≥4% of HbA2
  •  ≤5% of HbF 

Thalassaemia, a disorder affecting millions around the world, demands attention and action. The International Thalassaemia Day 2023 theme ‘BE AWARE.SHARE.CARE.: Strengthening Education to Bridge the Thalassaemia Care Gap,’ stresses the significance of education in providing proper care to those affected by this condition. It signifies an increased focus on quality care and better access to treatment to bridge the gap in thalassaemia care.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: An infant was admitted with failure to thrive. His reports show hypoglycemia, high glutamine, and uracil levels in urine. Gastric tube feeding was not tolerated and the child became comatose.  Parenteral dextrose was given after which the child recovered in 24 hours. What is the likely enzyme defect?
questions.solution:
This infant with failure to thrive, hypoglycemia, elevated levels of glutamine and uracil levels most likely has hyperammonemia type 2. This condition occurs due to the deficiency of the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase.

There is an accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate, which then enters into pyrimidine synthesis producing orotic acid and uracil and leading to orotic aciduria and high uracil in blood and urine. Since the ammonia from glutamine is not converted into urea, its level increases. Glutamate is not regenerated. Since glutamate is not available for transamination, amino acids cannot be used for gluconeogenesis. Hence, the glucose level drops in the blood.

Treatment:

  • Reducing intake of ammonia - Dietary protein, a metabolic source of ammonium, is restricted and caloric intake is provided by glucose and fat.
  • Increasing excretion of ammonia - Addition of phenylbutyrate, which scavenges nitrogen by combining with amino acids to form a more water-soluble product. This can be easily excreted by the kidneys.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A 23-year-old lady on oral combined contraceptive pills misses a single dose and reports to you in the OPD the next morning. What will be the most appropriate advice to this patient?

choices.text: Continue taking the next dose as scheduled
Double the next dose to make up for the missed dose
Interrupt the course and start taking the medications again on 5th day of bleeding
Start a fresh course of OCP again

questions.solution:
The most appropriate advice for this patient who has missed a single dose of the oral contraceptive pill (OCP) is to double the next dose to make up for the missed dose.

Missed dose considerations for oral combined contraceptive pills:

  • If a single dose is missed - a double dose can be taken on the next day to make up for the missed dose.
  • If two or more doses are missed on subsequent days - the last missed pill has to be taken along with the present pill and alternative methods of contraceptive must be used for the next 7 days.
  • If the pills were missed on the last week (days 15-21) - omit the hormone-free interval by finishing the hormonal pills in the current pack and starting the new pack from the next day.

questions.text: The gross specimen of the pancreas from a patient who died of acute pancreatitis is shown below. What is it suggestive of?
questions.solution:
The given specimen shows yellow nodules with areas of chalky-white deposits, which are suggestive of fat necrosis.

Fat necrosis results from the release of activated pancreatic lipases into the substance of the pancreas and the peritoneal cavity. These enzymes act on surrounding tissue to release fatty acids, which then combine with calcium to produce grossly visible chalky-white areas (fat saponification).

Histologic examination reveals foci of shadowy outlines of necrotic fat cells, with basophilic calcium deposits, surrounded by an inflammatory reaction.

The various types of necrosis include:

Type Example
Coagulative necrosis Infarcts in all organs except the brain
Caseous necrosis Tuberculosis
Liquefactive necrosis

Abscesses

Brain infarct

Wet gangrene
Fat necrosis Pancreatitis, Breast
Fibrinoid necrosis

Vasculitis

Aschoff bodies

Malignant hypertension

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 μm) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidean parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain positive oocysts in the image are identified as Cystoisospora.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are long and oval-shaped, which stain pink to red with Kinyoun staining.

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Property  Cryptosporidium Cyclospora Cystoisospora
Sporulated oocyst 4-6 μm, round,  contains four sporozoites 8-12 μm, round, contains 2 sporocyst each having two sporozoites 23-36 μm, oval, contain two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites.
Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst

 

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cyclospora cayetanensis.

Modified acid-fast staining (like Kinyoun stain) showing oocysts of Cryptosporidium species.

In immunocompromised patients, the infection causes severe diarrhea similar to cholera and require hospitalization.

The diagnosis is made with stool microscopy. The cyst wall and sporoblasts are dyed red with the Ziehl–Neelsen (warm) or Kinyoun (cold) staining methods. Both methods have good specificity and therefore are useful as confirmatory tests.

The treatment is fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with painless generalized lymphadenopathy and weakness. Lymph node biopsy shows the following picture. Which of the following is not true for this condition?

choices.text: Possible transformation into diffuse large B-cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
The lymph biopsy shows closely packed back-to-back follicles of variable areas and very less inter-follicular area. It is suggestive of follicular lymphoma.

Follicular lymphoma usually follows an indolent waxing and waning course, not an aggressive course.

Lymph node (LN) biopsy shows a nodular pattern with centrocytes and centroblasts as shown below.

Immunophenotyping:

  • The cell of origin is germinal-center B cell, so it is positive for CD19, CD20, CD10, BCL6, and surface Ig.
  • BCL2 expression is positive in over 90% of cases.

Histologic transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL) occurs in 30 to 50% of cases.

Note: In contrast to follicular lymphoma, DLBCL has an aggressive course, shows a diffuse pattern of growth in lymph node biopsy and shows BCL-6 positivity.

questions.text: A patient with a history of sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker 3 days back has developed genital discharge resembling 'flow of seed' as shown below. What medium should be used for the culture of the discharge?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of gonococcal urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Thayer-Martin and modified Thayer-Martin media are used for the culture of this organism. Gonorrhoea may manifest as mucopurulent genital discharge which can be described as resembling 'flow of seed' (semen).

Thayer-Martin medium contains vancomycin, colistin and nystatin.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted disease caused by N. gonorrhea. The major symptoms include urethritis, vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria. In the laboratory diagnosis of N. gonorrhea, the discharge on Gram's stain reveals gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes. It acidifies glucose but not maltose in serum sugars. Stuart's medium is used for transport while Thayer-Martin agar is used as a selective medium used to isolate N. gonorrhoeae. Cultures can be obtained from chocolate agar or Mueller-Hinton agar. 

Stuart’s medium is the transport media used for Neisseria gonorrhea and Neisseria meningitides. It is a semisolid, non-nutrient medium. Charcoal present in the medium neutralizes certain bacterial inhibitors while a reducing agent prevents oxidation.

Related Pearl: Sexually transmitted infections

Genital herpes- caused by herpes simplex virus (human herpesvirus 1 and 2).

  • It appears as blisters (usually multiple) that lead to ulcer formation on breaking.
  • The ulcers are painful.

 

Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis- caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacterium granulomatis).

  • It usually causes beefy red genital ulcers that may bleed on touch.
  • The ulcers are usually painless.
  • Lymphadenopathy is usually absent but subcutaneous granulomas cause pseudo buboes. 
  • Microscopy shows Donovan bodies with closed safety pin appearance

The given images show genital ulcer in granuloma inguinale:

 

Chancroid/ Soft chancre- caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

  • Causes genital ulcers that are non indurated with undermined edges.
  • The ulcer is painful.
  • Multiple/ Kissing ulcers develop due to autoinoculation from the primary ulcer.
  • It usually causes tender unilateral inguinal buboes. 
  • Microscopy- School of fish/Railroad track appearance

 

Syphilitic chancre/ Hard chancre- caused by Treponema pallidum.

  • It presents as a small, button-like, indurated ulcer that is usually round/oval.
  • The ulcer is painless.
  • Causes painless lymphadenopathy.
  • Microscopy- Spirochetes seen on dark ground illumination.

 

Lymphogranuloma venereum- caused by Chlamydia trachomatis.

  • It usually presents with a transient single shallow ulcer that heals rapidly and usually goes unnoticed.
  • The secondary stage presents with tender inguinal buboes.
  • Groove sign is seen when the lymph nodes above and below the inguinal ligament are enlarged leading to the appearance of a groove.

The given images show the ulcer and the groove sign seen in LGV:

 

Gonorrhea- caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

  • It leads to purulent inflammation of the genital mucous membranes.
  • It may present as urethritis, cervicitis, epididymo‐orchitis, or pelvic inflammatory disease.
  • The usual presentation is acute urethritis with complaints of burning dysuria and purulent discharge.

The given image shows purulent genital inflammation due to gonorrhea:

questions.text: A patient admitted to an ICU spiked a fever and his blood culture was positive for gram-positive cocci in chains, which are catalase-negative. He was being given ceftazidime and amikacin via a central venous line for the past week. Following this, you started him on vancomycin but his blood culture remained positive for the same organism even after 2 weeks of therapy. Which of the following is the most likely organism causing the infection?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) infection.

Gram-positive cocci in chains that are catalase-negative suggest that the organism belongs to Streptococcaceae family. Positive culture after 2 weeks of vancomycin therapy suggests resistance to vancomycin.

Option A: Streptococcus pyogenes are sensitive to vancomycin and are not commonly implicated in central venous line infections.

Option B: Viridans streptococci are usually mouth commensals and are sensitive to vancomycin.

Option D: Coagulase-negative staphylococci are gram-positive cocci in clusters which are catalase-positive. Hence, they can be ruled out.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive. Further examination shows generalized hypotonia and hepatomegaly. Chest X-ray image shows massive cardiomegaly. Microscopy of a muscle biopsy is shown in the given image. Which of the following is the treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical symptoms of hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and cardiomegaly, along with muscle biopsy showing vacuoles are suggestive of Pompe's disease. 

Pompe's disease (type II glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a mutation in alpha-1,4-glucosidase (also known as acid maltase), a lysosomal enzyme. A defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of glycogen in the lysosomes of peripheral, voluntary muscles and progresses to involve the cardiac muscle and diaphragm. Clinical features include hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), cardiomyopathy, hepatomegaly, and failure to thrive. Myozyme 

The treatment for Pompe disease is recombinant enzyme alglucosidase alfa (Myozyme), which can prevent worsening or reverse cardiac and skeletal abnormalities.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with the given rash after he had taken NSAIDs for his knee pain. He reported that he developed the same rash in the same location 6 months ago when he took the same drugs for back pain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The recurrence of hyperpigmentation occurring at the same site with the use of the same drug is characteristic of fixed drug eruption.

Fixed drug eruption is one of the most common drug-induced exanthems. The acute erythematous and bullous stages of fixed eruption characteristically settle leaving residual slate-brown hyperpigmentation, especially in those with darker skin types. The genitalia and perianal area are often affected.

Option A: Drug hypersensitivity is an immune-mediated reaction to a drug of which symptoms ranging from mild to severe include rash, anaphylaxis, and serum sickness.

Option B: Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) is an acquired hypermelanosis occurring after cutaneous inflammation or injury e.g., acne vulgaris, atopic dermatitis, and impetigo.

Option D: Drug-induced hypermelanosis is localized or generalized hyperpigmentation that can be caused by a wide range of medications and chemicals. eg. busulphan.  It doesn't necessarily occur at the same site with the reintroduction of drugs.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of AIDS presents to the OPD with fever, chills, weight loss and the cutaneous lesions shown below. The microscopic examination of the lesions revealed predominant neutrophilic infiltration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a patient with HIV infections and the violaceous lesions with a neutrophilic infiltrate is suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis.

Bacillary angiomatosis is seen in severely immunocompromised patients and is caused by B. henselae or B. quintana. It is characterized by neovascular proliferative lesions involving the skin. It consists of lobular proliferation of small blood vessels lined by enlarged endothelial cells interspersed with mixed infiltrates of neutrophils and lymphocytes, with a predominance of the former.

Both bacillary angiomatosis and Kaposi's sarcoma can have the clinical presentation mentioned in the question. However, the major differentiating factor is the microscopic examination:

  • Bacillary angiomatosis predominantly has mixed infiltrate accompanied by neutrophils with clumps of bacilli.
  • Kaposi's sarcoma predominantly has plasma cells and lymphocytic infiltrates.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was initiated on haloperidol therapy. 2 days later he presented to the OPD with deviation of his eyes,  asymmetric neck posture and inability to open his mouth completely. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of deviation of the eyes (oculogyric crisis), asymmetric position of the head or neck (torticollis) and inability to open the mouth (trismus) are pointing towards a diagnosis of haloperidol-induced acute dystonia.

These extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) occur due to the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors.

Acute dystonia is more commonly associated with high potency typical antipsychotics like haloperidol and occurs within 1 to 5 days of initiation of therapy. Benztropine or diphenhydramine may be used for treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital with a fever and cough. She has a history of repeated chest infections for several years and coughs up yellow-green purulent sputum with some streaky hemoptysis. What could be the underlying condition based on the CT given below?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT showing signet ring sign is suggestive of bronchiectasis which can be due to cystic fibrosis.

A history of repeated chest infections is an indication of cystic fibrosis and a major risk factor for the development of bronchiectasis.

questions.text: A patient presented with diplopia to the casualty. On examination, the left pupil was dilated. Both direct and consensual light reflexes were lost in the affected eye. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that the patient has III nerve (oculomotor nerve) palsy.

Absence of contraction of the pupil in both direct and consensual reflex suggests a lesion in the efferent pathway of the affected eye. This is III nerve/oculomotor palsy.

Light reflex consists of direct and consensual reflexes.

When light is shone in an eye,

  • Constriction of the pupil of the same eye is called direct reflex.
  • Constriction of the contralateral pupil is called consensual reflex/indirect reflex

For the light reflex,

  • Afferent nerve fiber is the II cranial nerve (optic nerve).
  • Efferent nerve fiber is the III cranial nerve (oculomotor nerve)-Bilaterally

In II nerve palsy, there will be a loss of direct reflex in the affected eye and loss of consensual light reflex in the opposite eye.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman comes to you with progressive heartburn and difficulty in swallowing. She also describes episodes of painful blanching and bluish discoloration of her fingers and toes on exposure to cold. The following findings are noted on examination. Antibodies to which of the following are most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of the patient in the above case scenario and the image showing calcinosis are the characteristic findings of the CREST syndrome or limited scleroderma. Patients with this condition characteristically have antibodies directed against centromeric proteins (anti-centromere antibodies).

CREST syndrome is characterized by the following:

  • Calcinosis
  • Raynaud phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

In the esophagus, progressive atrophy and fibrous replacement of the muscularis propria leads to hypomotility and dysphagia. The lower 2/3 of the esophagus develops a rubber-hose–like inflexibility. The associated dysfunction of the lower esophageal sphincter gives rise to gastroesophageal reflux, Barrett metaplasia, and stricture.
